msItem.title: List of contents
msItem.incipit: Adrianus abbas greca pingua peritus floruit.
msItem.explicit: Wulstanus baculum in marmore fixit. qui a nullo alio anelli potuit.

msItem.author: John of Tynemouth
msItem.title: Sanctilogium Angliae Walliae Scotiae et Hiberniae
msItem.incipit: Adrianus nacione affricanus comes et cooperator
msItem.explicit: sed ab epantu diectus plane dixit.
msItem.colophon: Perfectum est hoc opus wlgariter intitulatum De sanctis Anglie. Ad laudem et honorem omnipotentis dei. ac sancte Cantuar’ ecclesie. ex Impensis Reuerendi in cristo patris domini Thome Goleston eiusdem ecclesie Prioris. Ac sacrarum litterarum professoris egregii. Per me Jacobum Neell’ Normannum ac Rothomagi natum. Anno verbi incarnati .1.4.9.9. Deo gracias.

listBibl.bibl: Carl Horstmann, ed., Nova legenda Anglie (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1901).

msItem.note: Additions by Sir John Prise on leaves originally ruled for two columns but otherwise blank, copied from London, British Library, Cotton MS. Vespasian A. xiv.

msItem.rubric:
De primo statu Landanensis ecclesie
Excerpta de pervetusto Libro de vitis sanctorum Britanie
msItem.incipit: Anno ab incarnatione domini c l vi ᵗº Lucius britannorum Rex ad eleutherium apostolica sedis papam legatos suos scilicet eluanum et meduuinum misit, implorantes vt iuxta eius ammonitionem cristianus fieret quod ab eo impetrauit.
msItem.note: The text ends abruptly, leaving a blank space for the Welsh conclusion (ed. Evans, p. 78).

listBibl.bibl: Ed. J. Gwenogvryn Evans and John Rhys, The Text of the Book of Llan Dâv, Series of Welsh Texts 4 (Oxford, 1893), 68–78.

Ed. W. J. Rees, The Liber Landavensis, Llyfr Teilo, or, The Ancient Register of the Cathedral Church of Llandaff, Society for the Publication of Ancient Welsh Manuscripts 1 (Llandovery: Rees, 1840), 65–75.

msItem.title: Vita sancti Dubricii
msItem.rubric: Incipit Vita sancti Durbricij Archiepiscopi vrbis Legionum xviij Kl Decembris
msItem.incipit: Quidam Rex Ercychi regionis Pepiau nomine clavorauc uocatus britannice Latine vero spumosus qui super inimicos suos iuit in expeditionem
msItem.explicit: cum data benedictione et cum donatione omnibus auxiliantibus ad inceptum opus.

listBibl.bibl: Ed. J. Gwenogvryn Evans and John Rhys, The Text of the Book of Llan Dâv, Series of Welsh Texts 4 (Oxford, 1893), 78–96.

Ed. W. J. Rees, The Liber Landavensis, Llyfr Teilo, or, The Ancient Register of the Cathedral Church of Llandaff, Society for the Publication of Ancient Welsh Manuscripts 1 (Llandovery: Rees, 1840), 75–83.

msItem.title: Vita sancti Bernaci
msItem.incipit: Elegit sibi dominus virum de filiis israel iuxta cor suum bernacium nomine venustis ornatum moribus titulisque virtutum insignibus excellentem.
msItem.explicit: quando infundebatur frigida permanebat. Nec magis igne
msItem.note: The following leaf has been excised, ending before the conclusion (ed. Rees, p. 11).

listBibl.bibl: Ed. W. J. Rees, Lives of the Cambro British Saints, of the Fifth and Immediate Succeeding Centuries, Society for the Publication of Ancient Welsh Manuscripts 4 (Llandsvery: Rees, 1853), 1–12.

supportDesc.extent: i (modern paper endleaf) + 4 (medieval endleaves and contents list, pp. i–viii) + 298 (pp. 1–596) + 4 (pp. 597-604, medieval and early modern endleaves), i (modern paper endleaf) 365 270
supportDesc.foliation: Early modern pagination. A nineteenth-century hand has annotated pp. 581–596 with further numbers, pp. 585–600, but the original pagination is accurate.

collation.formula: 14 (pp. i–viii), 2–378 (pp. 1–576), 384 (pp. 577–584), 398–2 (pp. 585–596; 2nd and 8th excised), 304 (pp. 597–604; 3rd and 4th partially cut away).

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in red for 2 columns of 46 lines, ruled space 240 150

decoDesc.decoNote: Floriated border in gold leaf and colours on the opening page (p. 1). (Pächt and Alexander i. 796)
Text opens with a nine-line initial in gold leaf on a red and blue background (p. 1).
New lives open with three-line initials in blue with red pen flourishing.
New sections open with coloured initials, alternating between blue and red.

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard, 19th century.

origin.p: The colophon (p. 581) records that the book was written by Jacobus Neell, a Norman from Rouen.

history.provenance: Canterbury, Kent, Benedictine cathedral priory of Holy Trinity or Christ Church: the colophon (p. 581) indicates that the book was commissioned and paid for by Thomas Goldston, prior of Canterbury from 1495–1517 (MLGB3).

According to a pencil note in the official copy of the catalogue this manuscript contained the inscription Olim possedit Jac. Ofcote (?) miles, but this appears to have been lost when the volume was rebound.
history.acquisition: Bequeathed by him to the Bodleian in 1735.

recordHist.source:
Description by Andrew Dunning (November 2023). Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (A. Hackman, Catalogi codicum manuscriptorum Bibliothecæ Bodleianæ pars quarta codices viri admodum reverendi Thomæ Tanneri, S.T.P., episcopi Asaphensis, complectens, Quarto Catalogues IV, repr. 1966, with corrections, from the ed. of 1860). Decoration, localization and date follow Pächt and Alexander (1966). Summary Catalogue, Vol. 3, p. 82
Quarto Catalogue, Col. 18

ref.title: MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: A. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts in Oxford Libraries (1984), no. 704

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised with consultation of original.
